Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts law implies in every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy rights by the landlord or by those acting on the landlord’s behalf. G.L. c. 186, § 14; see, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts and states that “[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy,” citing prior cases. It further defines “quiet enjoyment” as freedom from serious interferences with tenancy and ties this doctrine to G.L. c. 186, § 14, confirming that the statute and common law protect tenants against substantial interference by landlords or those acting for them. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts implies such a covenant in every residential tenancy and that G.L. c. 186, § 14 enforces it.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: A substantial or significant interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises, especially where it involves violations of the State Sanitary Code or conditions affecting health and safety, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Watson v. Fitchburg Hous. Auth., 424 Mass. 193, 195–97 (1997); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a very substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment (here, extreme late-night bar noise rendering apartments not reasonably habitable) constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and supports constructive eviction. However, it does not discuss the State Sanitary Code, health and safety violations, or tie the breach specifically to such regulatory or health/safety conditions. Thus it supports the “substantial interference with use and enjoyment” aspect, but not the Sanitary Code/health-safety component of the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant in each of these consolidated actions for rent successfully raised constructive eviction as a defense… The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did… they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 arises where the landlord, after receiving notice of serious conditions affecting habitability, fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them within a reasonable time. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct, and explains that such negligence is shown where a landlord has notice or reason to know of a hazardous condition (here, lead paint) and fails to take appropriate corrective measures. It also cites Cruz for the principle that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects often violates § 14. This aligns with the proposition that landlord liability under § 14 arises when, after notice of serious habitability conditions, the landlord fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them within a reasonable time.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures. … [A] landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 where a landlord, with notice of serious habitability-related code violations, fails adequately to correct them. The SJC holds that such negligent omissions, when it is foreseeable that they will substantially impair the value of the premises, constitute a violation of § 14, thus supporting the proposition that liability arises when the landlord does not take reasonable remedial steps within a reasonable time after notice. While the opinion does not use the exact phrasing "reasonable time," its reasoning is fully consistent with that standard.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code, including failure to provide hot water, can constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–04 (1979); Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats loss of heat and inadequate hot water—both State Sanitary Code violations—as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and ties habitability to the absence of substantial Sanitary Code violations. While framed in warranty/abatement terms rather than the statutory phrase “quiet enjoyment,” Massachusetts cases treat substantial Sanitary Code violations like lack of heat or hot water as the kind of serious condition that substantially interferes with the tenant’s interest in the premises. This case is therefore good authority that failure to provide adequate hot water (and heat) can amount to a substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the dwelling.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The landlord would have us avert our eyes from the clear teaching of Hemingway. ‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969)…."

Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code, including failure to provide hot water, can constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.support_reasoning: This passage is from Justice Quirico’s separate concurrence/dissent and focuses on implying a landlord’s contractual obligation to comply with minimum standards set by the State Sanitary Code and on making that obligation mutually dependent with rent payment. It discusses habitability and statutory code violations in the context of rent abatement and implied covenants, not "quiet enjoyment" under G.L. c. 186, §14 or an analogous doctrine. There is no holding or reasoning here that violations of the State Sanitary Code, such as failure to provide hot water, constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment, so the case does not support the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition cited.
Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt: “This case returns to us…for computation by the trial judge of the damages owed to a tenant by his landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability… the judge had awarded damages…for violations of the State Sanitary Code… We also agree with the judge that McKenna is not entitled to receive damages for the minor code violations in this case. As we emphasized in our earlier opinion, not every defect gives rise to a diminution in rental value, and it has been held that isolated violations may be found not to constitute a breach of the warranty of habitability.”
